awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: A Sustainable and Connected Community-Scale Food System to Empower Consumers, Farmers, and Retailers
awd_abstract_narration:
A complex network of stakeholders, resources, activities, and information move food from farm to plate through a soil to soil food system (FS). To ensure the health of this system, especially through times of crisis and instability, all of the system's stakeholders (e.g., residents, food-producers, researchers, and policy-makers) need fresh, up-to-date information, something only possible at scale through the aid of community members. This project lays the foundations for a sustainable, community-driven data collection tool that will simultaneously help community members to better understand their food system by answering questions like "Where can I find healthy, fresh, low-cost food?" while encouraging participation in the food system by helping to keep data fresh and up-to-date. This planning proposal will develop a proof-of-concept, using image recognition (e.g., at retail stores or farm stands) to streamline the process of recording information about the availability, price, types, and other characteristics of produce available at produce displays. The project will also work with community members to drive adoption of the tool through healthy eating workshops and data-collection competitions. 

Working collaboratively with non-profit and local government community partners in the Western New York (WNY) food system, the project team of researchers and stakeholder will develop data collection platform called REAP (Research, Education, Action, And Policy for Resilience) to allow crowdsourced data to augment an existing WNY food system dashboard. For example, by allowing for crowdsourced produce price data, the team can analyze how this information impacts the behaviors of both consumers and suppliers in the food system. The project will advance the state of the art in computer vision and uncertain data management by developing techniques to correlate multiple sources of information in images while ignoring distractors, and for tracking the system's confidence in the resulting information through the entire data presentation pipeline. The proposed work also includes a meta-analysis, using pre- and post- surveys, as well as graph analysis on the data captured through REAP, to examine how the availability and flow of co-produced information and food-related behavioral actions affect food system stakeholders. REAP lays the groundwork for ongoing efforts to map the WNY food system, simultaneously studying both urban and rural participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
This project laid the groundwork for an information platform to support and sustain a healthy, equitable, and resilient food system in Western New York (WNY).  A food system is the soil-to-soil system that encompasses production, processing, distribution, acquisition, and consumption of food, and management of food-related waste in a region. A healthy food system depends on information, resources, technologies, stakeholders, relationships, policies and laws that shape and influence how food moves through the system: from farm to plate and back to the farm again.  

The fragility of food systems was illuminated by the COVID-19 pandemic, and further exacerbated by it. Disruptions in supply chains led to supermarkets and grocery stores running out of particular foods during the acute phase of the pandemic. Sources of supplemental food assistance (e.g., food banks, school lunch programs, and elder-care programs) were strained from the logistical challenges presented by a large-scale quarantine. At the same time farmers were forced to discard critically needed produce, lacking the logistical resources to harvest or transport it.  

Through this award, we developed a community-powered tool to help communities find fresh, low-cost produce at nearby stores.  The focus of this tool is a smartphone app (a progressive web-app) that community members can install to view and search nearby stores for specific produce by type, price, and availability of specific payment options (e.g., a store that accefood assistance).   

The app is community powered: The data in the app stays fresh through community members submitting availability and pricing information, along with pictures.  To make the feedback process as easy as possible, we developed a machine learning model capable of identifying produce in a grocery store setting, and of identifying and recognizing image text such as pricing information.  Community members need only take a picture of a produce stand at a store, let the app automatically tag produce and their prices.  Corrections are only needed in the rare situations where the app guesses wrong. 

This tool lays the groundwork for increased community engagement with the local food system.  Apart from the direct opportunities for community members to engage with their food system, the app provides a channel to better coordinate resource usage.  For example, the app makes it easier to locate alternative produce options that vary in availability and location, options like community gardens, farm trucks, or pop-up food stands.  Such a resource could have been incredibly helpful in the wake of the horrific May 2022 Tops shooting in Buffalo's East Side Neighborhood; In addition to the immediate impacts of the tragedy, the closure of the store left approximately 1/3 of the neighborhood's residents without a food source within walking distance.  Pop-up food stands were quickly arranged by the community to fill this need, but coordinating and communicating their locations was an ongoing challenge during the crisis period. 

Community engagement was a critical objective throughout the proposal: Team members established relationships with organizations including Urban Fruits and Veggies, and the African Heritage Co-op.  Most notably, this award allowed us to participate in and contribute to the Food Future WNY project, which is an ongoing effort to map Western New York's Food System.  Among other accomplishments, at the Food Future WNY report launch, we presented the results of a study to better understand the social networks of the WNY Food System's stakeholders. 

Last, but not least, was an effort to understand the food system as a cycle; By predicting food waste, we can better understand the factors that lead to food waste and begin to propose strategies for mitigating it.  We used daily records of food waste, customer counts, and sales volume, for a Florida-based restaurant to develop such a model, identifying predictive analytics as a useful framework for estimating daily food waste.


Last Modified: 02/12/2024
Modified by: Oliver A Kennedy

    Oliver A Kennedy
    Mapping Food Resources
  • The FoodNet webapp provides a front-end to the extracted data, making it easy to both explore nearby sources of produce, and to provide feedback.
    The FoodNet Team Members
    Creative Commons
    Oliver A Kennedy
    Web App
  • The FoodNet app allows community members to quickly provide feedback about changes in produce pricing or availability by using machine learning models to automatically extract relevant information from a photo of the produce stand.
    The FoodNet Team Members
    Creative Commons
    Oliver A Kennedy
    Community Feedback
  • FoodNet relies on the Vizier data processing platform to integrate data from a variety of sources, including user-provided data, government data portals, and community-built inventories.
    The FoodNet Team Members
    Creative Commons
    Oliver A Kennedy
    Data Processing
  • FoodNet is powered by a machine learning model that can recognize produce in-situ and extract pricing information from scene text.
    The FoodNet Team Members

por.por_txt_cntn:
This project laid the groundwork for an information platform to support and sustain a healthy, equitable, and resilient food system in Western New York (WNY). A food system is the soil-to-soil system that encompasses production, processing, distribution, acquisition, and consumption of food, and management of food-related waste in a region. A healthy food system depends on information, resources, technologies, stakeholders, relationships, policies and laws that shape and influence how food moves through the system: from farm to plate and back to the farm again.




The fragility of food systems was illuminated by the COVID-19 pandemic, and further exacerbated by it. Disruptions in supply chains led to supermarkets and grocery stores running out of particular foods during the acute phase of the pandemic. Sources of supplemental food assistance (e.g., food banks, school lunch programs, and elder-care programs) were strained from the logistical challenges presented by a large-scale quarantine. At the same time farmers were forced to discard critically needed produce, lacking the logistical resources to harvest or transport it.




Through this award, we developed a community-powered tool to help communities find fresh, low-cost produce at nearby stores. The focus of this tool is a smartphone app (a progressive web-app) that community members can install to view and search nearby stores for specific produce by type, price, and availability of specific payment options (e.g., a store that accefood assistance).




The app is community powered: The data in the app stays fresh through community members submitting availability and pricing information, along with pictures. To make the feedback process as easy as possible, we developed a machine learning model capable of identifying produce in a grocery store setting, and of identifying and recognizing image text such as pricing information. Community members need only take a picture of a produce stand at a store, let the app automatically tag produce and their prices. Corrections are only needed in the rare situations where the app guesses wrong.




This tool lays the groundwork for increased community engagement with the local food system. Apart from the direct opportunities for community members to engage with their food system, the app provides a channel to better coordinate resource usage. For example, the app makes it easier to locate alternative produce options that vary in availability and location, options like community gardens, farm trucks, or pop-up food stands. Such a resource could have been incredibly helpful in the wake of the horrific May 2022 Tops shooting in Buffalo's East Side Neighborhood; In addition to the immediate impacts of the tragedy, the closure of the store left approximately 1/3 of the neighborhood's residents without a food source within walking distance. Pop-up food stands were quickly arranged by the community to fill this need, but coordinating and communicating their locations was an ongoing challenge during the crisis period.




Community engagement was a critical objective throughout the proposal: Team members established relationships with organizations including Urban Fruits and Veggies, and the African Heritage Co-op. Most notably, this award allowed us to participate in and contribute to the Food Future WNY project, which is an ongoing effort to map Western New York's Food System. Among other accomplishments, at the Food Future WNY report launch, we presented the results of a study to better understand the social networks of the WNY Food System's stakeholders.




Last, but not least, was an effort to understand the food system as a cycle; By predicting food waste, we can better understand the factors that lead to food waste and begin to propose strategies for mitigating it. We used daily records of food waste, customer counts, and sales volume, for a Florida-based restaurant to develop such a model, identifying predictive analytics as a useful framework for estimating daily food waste.
